title: Flash local-with-fileaccess Sandbox Bypass
vulnerability_information:
The proof of concept attached will exploit the implementation of flash in some browsers that will bypass the local-with-fileaccess sandbox. By encoding in ignored file:// uri characters, and navigating to another page with a decoder script. one is able to read arbitrary files AND parse it to the parent page, bypassing the local sandbox. 
The flash applet has a default mode in which it will parse file content and another mode (by setting flashvars) that will parse the length of the content of a file. And iframe within those 2 makes sure that the original window is persistent and the applet in the iframe will only move the iframe, the data is then passed by localstorage, and if recieved by poc.html, the iframe is reset.
A quick overview of what the poc is doing, in which order.
-Determine the length of the content from the file through  the flash applet with mode 2
-Determine the maximum amount of space which can be used for leaking the data (chrome uses a max of 260)
-Since every character uses 8 bits, divide that amount by 8, set as maximum chars in one 'transmission'.
-Determine  how much 'transmissions are needed' to get the entire file
-Walk through file to get the entire file by appending all requested parts to variable 'total'
-Call whatever callback function back.


Demonstrated in poc2.html:
-The impact of this attack is increased by the ability to download arbitrary remote files (Cross origin) by systematically downloading those files to a know predictable location. (using the download= attribute in a <a >tag). This link will be automatically clicked.  Now as long as the user is opening the file from a Drive:/User/Username location. We can simply predict the path to read the downloaded file on windows vista+ (Or any other OS with a default download folder for that matter).
-This stage of exploitation enables an attacker to access a file with the auth of the user the following 'attack use cases' arise:
1. Attacker could access and send users web-mail to his sown erver. (try using 'https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/feed/atom' in poc2 while logged in with gmail)
2. Attacker could get XSRF-tokens. To bypass such protections.
I could imagine there are countless other possibilities. 
-You might notice that loading the Hackerone page is painfully slow. However, In targeted attacks a attacker could filter the desirable data in the flash applet itself.



Now for the exploit itself, I acknowledge that the exploit might look very complex.
Which is why I added a 'frontend' that is tested under the following conditions.
OS:Windows 8
Browser: Google Chrome 32.0.1700.107 m
vulnerability_information_html:
The proof of concept attached will exploit the implementation of flash in some browsers that will bypass the local-with-fileaccess sandbox. By encoding in ignored file:// uri characters, and navigating to another page with a decoder script. one is able to read arbitrary files AND parse it to the parent page, bypassing the local sandbox.
The flash applet has a default mode in which it will parse file content and another mode (by setting flashvars) that will parse the length of the content of a file. And iframe within those 2 makes sure that the original window is persistent and the applet in the iframe will only move the iframe, the data is then passed by localstorage, and if recieved by poc.html, the iframe is reset.
A quick overview of what the poc is doing, in which order.
-Determine the length of the content from the file through the flash applet with mode 2
-Determine the maximum amount of space which can be used for leaking the data (chrome uses a max of 260)
-Since every character uses 8 bits, divide that amount by 8, set as maximum chars in one 'transmission'.
-Determine how much 'transmissions are needed' to get the entire file
-Walk through file to get the entire file by appending all requested parts to variable 'total'
-Call whatever callback function back.

Demonstrated in poc2.html:
-The impact of this attack is increased by the ability to download arbitrary remote files (Cross origin) by systematically downloading those files to a know predictable location. (using the download= attribute in a <a >tag). This link will be automatically clicked. Now as long as the user is opening the file from a Drive:/User/Username location. We can simply predict the path to read the downloaded file on windows vista+ (Or any other OS with a default download folder for that matter).
-This stage of exploitation enables an attacker to access a file with the auth of the user the following 'attack use cases' arise:

  1. Attacker could access and send users web-mail to his sown erver. (try using 'https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/feed/atom' in poc2 while logged in with gmail)
  2. Attacker could get XSRF-tokens. To bypass such protections. I could imagine there are countless other possibilities. -You might notice that loading the Hackerone page is painfully slow. However, In targeted attacks a attacker could filter the desirable data in the flash applet itself.

Now for the exploit itself, I acknowledge that the exploit might look very complex.
Which is why I added a 'frontend' that is tested under the following conditions.
OS:Windows 8
Browser: Google Chrome 32.0.1700.107 m

activities.message: Video demonstration of the proof of concept: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3n_ErklMEC4
activities.markdown_message: Video demonstration of the proof of concept: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3n_ErklMEC4

activities.message:
I recognize the behavior described to get a remote file (poc2.html) is more a design issue/flaw in Google Chrome itself. Not as much fault of flash. I have filed a seperate bug directly at the vendor for this behavior (Chromium bug tracker).

I have thought about a solution for such attacks. Since there will always exist flaws in the implementation of flash (From the browser), I think it would be a good Idea to only allow the opening of windows that are separately defined eg the url defined as constant before the actual flash 'program' would be run. In an attempt to prevent 'variable' data to leak. However, this would obviously come with the consequence that the usability of URLloader would decrease.
activities.markdown_message:
I recognize the behavior described to get a remote file (poc2.html) is more a design issue/flaw in Google Chrome itself. Not as much fault of flash. I have filed a seperate bug directly at the vendor for this behavior (Chromium bug tracker).

I have thought about a solution for such attacks. Since there will always exist flaws in the implementation of flash (From the browser), I think it would be a good Idea to only allow the opening of windows that are separately defined eg the url defined as constant before the actual flash 'program' would be run. In an attempt to prevent 'variable' data to leak. However, this would obviously come with the consequence that the usability of URLloader would decrease.

activities.message:
Thanks for reporting this bug and thanks for the video, which is instructive.

One quick question: are you able to mount this attack directly from a web site?
Or does the evil SWF file need to be downloaded to the filesystem file?
Browsers tend to have click-through dialogs for SWF downloads and Chrome has
a "dangerous file type" download click-through for SWF files.
But if you could mount the cross-site theft directly from a web site without
any user click-through then it would be really serious.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for reporting this bug and thanks for the video, which is instructive.

One quick question: are you able to mount this attack directly from a web site?
Or does the evil SWF file need to be downloaded to the filesystem file?
Browsers tend to have click-through dialogs for SWF downloads and Chrome has
a "dangerous file type" download click-through for SWF files.
But if you could mount the cross-site theft directly from a web site without
any user click-through then it would be really serious.

activities.message:
It is required for it to be opened on a file:// url
Beware though. I can modify this exploit, using data uri I can embed the .swf directly inside the html content. I would then also save every page htmlcontent as 'string'  and set a get parameter for the different 'pages' to track which of those should be 'written'

This results in ONE single .html file that must be openend in order for the same exploit to occur. Bypassing the 'dangerous file type' (plus the fact that only a single file has to be downloaded this way). 

Afaik this attack would need another stage to directly attack from a website. So to answer your question. If attacking from a website itself , no. This exploit would not be able to run completely without user interaction. 
Downloading the file however could be automated, taking only one click to exploit a machine.

Afaik this attack would need another stage to directly attack from a website. So to answer your question. If attacking from a website itself , no. This exploit would not be able to run completely without user interaction.
Downloading the file however could be automated, taking only one click to exploit a machine.

activities.message: If required I can upload the poc modified to consist of only a single file. Is there any way I could upload the other poc in which all components are embedded in a single file ? Or could I email it to someone one the team ? The upload form does not show for me on the normal comment section

activities.message: kinine: oh, that's a _really_ interesting angle. Are you saying that you can bypass the SWF warning by embedding the SWF as a data: URL inside an HTML file?
activities.markdown_message: kinine: oh, that's a really interesting angle. Are you saying that you can bypass the SWF warning by embedding the SWF as a data: URL inside an HTML file?

activities.message: That is exactly what I am saying. I just provided the poc disected because the code (imho) is very complex already.
activities.markdown_message: That is exactly what I am saying. I just provided the poc disected because the code (imho) is very complex already.

activities.message: I would be happy to provide the other proof of concept that demonstrates that ability to 'pack' the .swf into the html file itself. If provided with an email or another confidential way of providing that file.
activities.markdown_message: I would be happy to provide the other proof of concept that demonstrates that ability to 'pack' the .swf into the html file itself. If provided with an email or another confidential way of providing that file.

activities.message:
A quick update: I have also informed chrome of some design flaws that make this exploit possible (the a href cross-domain etc).
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_h9BTUElG8 shows how, when packing the exploit into a .html file. It really only takes 1 single click to exploit the users machine.

activities.message: This is pretty slick technique, and I'd nominate it for an IBB reward. This issue looks like it might take a bit of back and forth with the Flash team, so I expect it's best if you're in direct communication with them. If you haven't already, could you please disclose this issue to Adobe and report back to us when a fix/mitigation is published?
activities.markdown_message: This is pretty slick technique, and I'd nominate it for an IBB reward. This issue looks like it might take a bit of back and forth with the Flash team, so I expect it's best if you're in direct communication with them. If you haven't already, could you please disclose this issue to Adobe and report back to us when a fix/mitigation is published?

activities.message: A quick update: Google chrome is currently looking the vulnerability of downloading arbitrary remote files without user consent (which really amplified the impact of this issue). I have already disclosed this issue to Adobe but I am currently still waiting for a response. I will report back as soon as I can.
activities.markdown_message: A quick update: Google chrome is currently looking the vulnerability of downloading arbitrary remote files without user consent (which really amplified the impact of this issue). I have already disclosed this issue to Adobe but I am currently still waiting for a response. I will report back as soon as I can.

activities.message:
The issue is published and fixed.
CVE-2014-0508
http://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/flash-player/apsb14-09.html
"These updates resolve a security bypass vulnerability that could lead to information disclosure (CVE-2014-0508)."
"Bas Venis (CVE-2014-0508)"
